item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Wowchemy’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further event details, including page elements such as image galleries, can be added to the body of this page.

item.title: –ü–æ—Å—Ç –ø–æ –ø—Ä–æ—à–µ–¥—à–µ–π –Ω–µ–¥–µ–ª–µ / Last week's post
item.description:
–°–æ–±—ã—Ç–∏—è / Events:

  • –ù–∞–ø–∏—Å–∞–ª–∞ –∫–æ–Ω—Ç—Ä–æ–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—ã –ø–æ –¥–∏—Å–∫—Ä–µ—Ç–Ω–æ–π –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏–∫–µ –∏ –ª–∏–Ω–µ–π–Ω–æ–π –∞–ª–≥–µ–±—Ä–µ. –¢–∞–∫–∂–µ —è –≤—ã–ø–æ–ª–Ω–∏–ª–∞ –∏—Ç–æ–≥–æ–≤—ã–π —Ç–µ—Å—Ç –ø–æ –∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∏–∏.
  • I wrote tests in discrete mathematics and linear algebra. Also I passed the history final test.

item.title: –Ø–∑—ã–∫–∏ –Ω–∞—É—á–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è / Scientific programming languages
item.description:
–Ø–∑—ã–∫–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è (–†—É—Å—Å–∫–∏–π)

–Ø–∑—ã–∫–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è - —ç—Ç–æ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ —è–∑—ã–∫–∏, –ø—Ä–µ–¥–Ω–∞–∑–Ω–∞—á–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –¥–ª—è –æ–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏—è –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º –∏ –∞–ª–≥–æ—Ä–∏—Ç–º–æ–≤, –ø–æ–∑–≤–æ–ª—è—é—â–∏—Ö –∫–æ–º–ø—å—é—Ç–µ—Ä—É –≤—ã–ø–æ–ª–Ω–∏—Ç—å —Ç–æ—Ç –∏–ª–∏ –∏–Ω–æ–π –≤—ã—á–∏—Å–ª–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω—ã–π –ø—Ä–æ—Ü–µ—Å—Å, –æ—Ä–≥–∞–Ω–∏–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å —É–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ —Ä–∞–∑–ª–∏—á–Ω—ã–º–∏ –æ–±—ä–µ–∫—Ç–∞–º–∏, –∏ —Ç. –ø. –û–Ω–∏ –ø—Ä–µ–¥—Å—Ç–∞–≤–ª—è—é—Ç –Ω–∞–±–æ—Ä –ª–µ–∫—Å–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö, —Å–∏–Ω—Ç–∞–∫—Å–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö –∏ —Å–µ–º–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö –ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏–ª, –æ–ø—Ä–µ–¥–µ–ª—è—é—â–∏—Ö –≤–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–π –≤–∏–¥ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º—ã –∏ –¥–µ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∏—è, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–µ –≤—ã–ø–æ–ª–Ω–∏—Ç –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª–Ω–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å (–≠–í–ú) –ø–æ–¥ –µ—ë —É–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ–º.

–Ø–∑—ã–∫–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª—è—é—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –¥–≤–µ –æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–Ω—ã–µ –∫–∞—Ç–µ–≥–æ—Ä–∏–∏: —è–∑—ã–∫–∏ –≤—ã—Å–æ–∫–æ–≥–æ —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω—è –∏ —è–∑—ã–∫–∏ –Ω–∏–∑–∫–æ–≥–æ —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω—è.

–Ø–∑—ã–∫–∏ –≤—ã—Å–æ–∫–æ–≥–æ —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω—è

–Ø–∑—ã–∫ –≤—ã—Å–æ–∫–æ–≥–æ —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω—è (high-level language) - —è–∑—ã–∫ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è, —Å—Ä–µ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–∞ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–≥–æ –æ–±–µ—Å–ø–µ—á–∏–≤–∞—é—Ç –æ–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–¥–∞—á–∏ –≤ –Ω–∞–≥–ª—è–¥–Ω–æ–º, –ª–µ–≥–∫–æ –≤–æ—Å–ø—Ä–∏–Ω–∏–º–∞–µ–º–æ–º –≤–∏–¥–µ, —É–¥–æ–±–Ω–æ–º –¥–ª—è –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Å—Ç–∞. –û–Ω –Ω–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏—Ç –æ—Ç –≤–Ω—É—Ç—Ä–µ–Ω–Ω–∏—Ö –º–∞—à–∏–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –∫–æ–¥–æ–≤ –≠–í–ú –ª—é–±–æ–≥–æ —Ç–∏–ø–∞, –ø–æ—ç—Ç–æ–º—É –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º—ã, –Ω–∞–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –Ω–∞ —è–∑—ã–∫–∞—Ö –≤—ã—Å–æ–∫–æ–≥–æ —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω—è, —Ç—Ä–µ–±—É—é—Ç –ø–µ—Ä–µ–≤–æ–¥–∞ –≤ –º–∞—à–∏–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∫–æ–¥—ã –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∞–º–∏ —Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å–ª—è—Ç–æ—Ä–∞ –ª–∏–±–æ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–ø—Ä–µ—Ç–∞—Ç–æ—Ä–∞. –ö —è–∑—ã–∫–∞–º –≤—ã—Å–æ–∫–æ–≥–æ —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω—è –æ—Ç–Ω–æ—Å—è—Ç Fortr, Python, JavaScript, C, C++, C#, Basic, Pascal, PHP, Ada –∏ –¥—Ä.

  • –§–æ—Ä—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω (Fortran) ‚Äî –ø–µ—Ä–≤—ã–π —è–∑—ã–∫ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è –≤—ã—Å–æ–∫–æ–≥–æ —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω—è, –ø–æ–ª—É—á–∏–≤—à–∏–π –ø—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–µ –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏–µ, –∏–º–µ—é—â–∏–π —Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å–ª—è—Ç–æ—Ä –∏ –∏—Å–ø—ã—Ç–∞–≤—à–∏–π –¥–∞–ª—å–Ω–µ–π—à–µ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–≤–∏—Ç–∏–µ. –†–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞–Ω –≤ –ø–µ—Ä–∏–æ–¥ —Å 1954 –ø–æ 1957 –≥–æ–¥ –≥—Ä—É–ø–ø–æ–π –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Å—Ç–æ–≤ –ø–æ–¥ —Ä—É–∫–æ–≤–æ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–æ–º –î–∂–æ–Ω–∞ –ë—ç–∫—É—Å–∞ –≤ –∫–æ—Ä–ø–æ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏ IBM. –ù–∞–∑–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ Fortran —è–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç—Å—è —Å–æ–∫—Ä–∞—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ–º –æ—Ç FORmula TRANslator (—Ñ–æ—Ä–º—É–ª—å–Ω—ã–π —Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å–ª—è—Ç–æ—Ä). –§–æ—Ä—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω —à–∏—Ä–æ–∫–æ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑—É–µ—Ç—Å—è –≤ –ø–µ—Ä–≤—É—é –æ—á–µ—Ä–µ–¥—å –¥–ª—è –Ω–∞—É—á–Ω—ã—Ö –∏ –∏–Ω–∂–µ–Ω–µ—Ä–Ω—ã—Ö –≤—ã—á–∏—Å–ª–µ–Ω–∏–π. –û–¥–Ω–æ –∏–∑ –ø—Ä–µ–∏–º—É—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤ —Å–æ–≤—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ –§–æ—Ä—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω–∞ ‚Äî –±–æ–ª—å—à–æ–µ –∫–æ–ª–∏—á–µ—Å—Ç–≤–æ –Ω–∞–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –Ω–∞ –Ω—ë–º –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º –∏ –±–∏–±–ª–∏–æ—Ç–µ–∫ –ø–æ–¥–ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, –¥–ª—è –º–∞—Ç—Ä–∏—á–Ω–æ–π –∞–ª–≥–µ–±—Ä—ã, –¥–∏—Ñ—Ñ–µ—Ä–µ–Ω—Ü–∏–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã—Ö —É—Ä–∞–≤–Ω–µ–Ω–∏–π, –∏–Ω—Ç–µ–≥—Ä–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã—Ö —É—Ä–∞–≤–Ω–µ–Ω–∏–π, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–π —Å—Ç–∞—Ç–∏—Å—Ç–∏–∫–∏ –∏ –¥—Ä.) –ù–∞–∏–±–æ–ª–µ–µ —Ä–∞—Å–ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–º–∏ –≤–µ—Ä—Å–∏—è–º–∏ —ç—Ç–æ–≥–æ —è–∑—ã–∫–∞ —è–≤–ª—è—é—Ç—Å—è –§–æ—Ä—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω IV, –§–æ—Ä—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω 77 –∏ –§–æ—Ä—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω 90. –ò—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑—É–µ—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –≤—Å–µ—Ö –∫–ª–∞—Å—Å–∞—Ö –≠–í–ú. –ü–æ—Å–ª–µ–¥–Ω—è—è –µ–≥–æ –≤–µ—Ä—Å–∏—è —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ–Ω—è–µ—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –≠–í–ú —Å –ø–∞—Ä–∞–ª–ª–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ–π –∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–æ–π.
  • –°–∏ (C) - –ú–Ω–æ–≥–æ—Ü–µ–ª–µ–≤–æ–π —è–∑—ã–∫ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è –≤—ã—Å–æ–∫–æ–≥–æ —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω—è, —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–π –î–µ–Ω–∏—Å–æ–º –†–∏—Ç—á–∏ –≤ –Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–µ 1970-—Ö –≥–≥. –Ω–∞ –±–∞–∑–µ —è–∑—ã–∫–∞ BCPL. –ò—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑—É–µ—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –º–∏–Ω–∏–≠–í–ú –∏ –ü–≠–í–ú. –Ø–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç—Å—è –±–∞–∑–æ–≤—ã–º —è–∑—ã–∫–æ–º –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–Ω–æ–π —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º—ã Unix , –æ–¥–Ω–∞–∫–æ –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ–Ω—è–µ—Ç—Å—è –∏ –≤–Ω–µ —ç—Ç–æ–π —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º—ã, –¥–ª—è –Ω–∞–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏—è –±—ã—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–¥–µ–π—Å—Ç–≤—É—é—â–∏—Ö –∏ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω—ã—Ö –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–Ω—ã—Ö –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –≤–∫–ª—é—á–∞—è –∏ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º—ã. –î–ª—è IBM PC –∏–º–µ–µ—Ç—Å—è —Ä—è–¥ –ø–æ–ø—É–ª—è—Ä–Ω—ã—Ö –≤–µ—Ä—Å–∏–π —è–∑—ã–∫–∞ –°–∏, –≤ —Ç–æ–º —á–∏—Å–ª–µ - Turbo C (—Ñ–∏—Ä–º—ã Borland), Microsoft C –∏ Quick C ( —Ñ–∏—Ä–º—ã Microsoft ), –∞ —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ Zortech C (—Ñ–∏—Ä–º—ã Symantec ). –ú–Ω–æ–≥–∏–µ –∏–∑ —É–∫–∞–∑–∞–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –≤–µ—Ä—Å–∏–π –æ–±–µ—Å–ø–µ—á–∏–≤–∞—é—Ç —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—É —Å –°–∏ –∏ –°–∏++.
  • –°–∏++ (C++) - –Ø–∑—ã–∫ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è –≤—ã—Å–æ–∫–æ–≥–æ —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω—è, —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–π –ë—å—è—Ä–Ω–æ–º –°—Ç—Ä–∞—É—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–ø–æ–º –Ω–∞ –±–∞–∑–µ —è–∑—ã–∫–∞ –°–∏. –Ø–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç—Å—è –µ–≥–æ —Ä–∞—Å—à–∏—Ä–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–π –≤–µ—Ä—Å–∏–µ–π, —Ä–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑—É—é—â–µ–π –ø—Ä–∏–Ω—Ü–∏–ø—ã –æ–±—ä–µ–∫—Ç–Ω–æ-–æ—Ä–∏–µ–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è. C++ —à–∏—Ä–æ–∫–æ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑—É–µ—Ç—Å—è –¥–ª—è —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–Ω–æ–≥–æ –æ–±–µ—Å–ø–µ—á–µ–Ω–∏—è –∏ —è–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç—Å—è –æ–¥–Ω–∏–º –∏–∑ —Å–∞–º—ã—Ö –ø–æ–ø—É–ª—è—Ä–Ω—ã—Ö —è–∑—ã–∫–æ–≤ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è. –°–∏–Ω—Ç–∞–∫—Å–∏—Å C++ —É–Ω–∞—Å–ª–µ–¥–æ–≤–∞–Ω –æ—Ç —è–∑—ã–∫–∞ C. –û–±–ª–∞—Å—Ç—å –µ–≥–æ –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è –≤–∫–ª—é—á–∞–µ—Ç —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–Ω–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º, —Ä–∞–∑–Ω–æ–æ–±—Ä–∞–∑–Ω—ã—Ö –ø—Ä–∏–∫–ª–∞–¥–Ω—ã—Ö –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º, –¥—Ä–∞–π–≤–µ—Ä–æ–≤ —É—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–π—Å—Ç–≤, –ø—Ä–∏–ª–æ–∂–µ–Ω–∏–π –¥–ª—è –≤—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–∏–≤–∞–µ–º—ã—Ö —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º, –≤—ã—Å–æ–∫–æ–ø—Ä–æ–∏–∑–≤–æ–¥–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω—ã—Ö —Å–µ—Ä–≤–µ—Ä–æ–≤, –∞ —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ –∫–æ–º–ø—å—é—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω—ã—Ö –∏–≥—Ä. –°—É—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤—É–µ—Ç –º–Ω–æ–∂–µ—Å—Ç–≤–æ —Ä–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–π —è–∑—ã–∫–∞ C++, –∫–∞–∫ –±–µ—Å–ø–ª–∞—Ç–Ω—ã—Ö, —Ç–∞–∫ –∏ –∫–æ–º–º–µ—Ä—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö –∏ –¥–ª—è —Ä–∞–∑–ª–∏—á–Ω—ã—Ö –ø–ª–∞—Ç—Ñ–æ—Ä–º. –ù–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, –Ω–∞ –ø–ª–∞—Ç—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–µ x86 —ç—Ç–æ GCC, Visual C++, Intel C++ Compiler, Embarcadero (Borland) C++ Builder –∏ –¥—Ä—É–≥–∏–µ. C++ –æ–∫–∞–∑–∞–ª –æ–≥—Ä–æ–º–Ω–æ–µ –≤–ª–∏—è–Ω–∏–µ –Ω–∞ –¥—Ä—É–≥–∏–µ —è–∑—ã–∫–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è, –≤ –ø–µ—Ä–≤—É—é –æ—á–µ—Ä–µ–¥—å –Ω–∞ Java –∏ C#. –î–ª—è IBM PC –Ω–∞–∏–±–æ–ª–µ–µ –ø–æ–ø—É–ª—è—Ä–Ω–æ–π —è–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç—Å—è —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º–∞ Turbo C++ —Ñ–∏—Ä–º—ã Borland (–°–®–ê).
  • C# (C Sharp) ‚Äì –æ–±—ä–µ–∫—Ç–Ω–æ-–æ—Ä–∏–µ–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–π —è—ã–∫ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è –æ–±—â–µ–≥–æ –Ω–∞–∑–Ω–∞—á–µ–Ω–∏—è, –†–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞–Ω –≤ 1998‚Äî2001 –≥–æ–¥–∞—Ö –≥—Ä—É–ø–ø–æ–π –∏–Ω–∂–µ–Ω–µ—Ä–æ–≤ –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω–∏–∏ Microsoft –ø–æ–¥ —Ä—É–∫–æ–≤–æ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–æ–º –ê–Ω–¥–µ—Ä—Å–∞ –•–µ–π–ª—Å–±–µ—Ä–≥–∞ –∏ –°–∫–æ—Ç—Ç–∞ –í–∏–ª—å—Ç–∞—É–º–æ—Ç–∞ –∫–∞–∫ —è–∑—ã–∫ —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∏ –ø—Ä–∏–ª–æ–∂–µ–Ω–∏–π –¥–ª—è –ø–ª–∞—Ç—Ñ–æ—Ä–º—ã Microsoft .NET Framework –∏ .NET Core. –í–ø–æ—Å–ª–µ–¥—Å—Ç–≤–∏–∏ –±—ã–ª —Å—Ç–∞–Ω–¥–∞—Ä—Ç–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω –∫–∞–∫ ECMA-334 –∏ ISO/IEC 23270. –ü–æ —Å–≤–æ–µ–º—É —Ö–∞—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–µ—Ä—É –æ–Ω –Ω–∞–ø–æ–º–∏–Ω–∞–µ—Ç —è–∑—ã–∫–∏ C++ –∏ Java –∏ –ø—Ä–µ–¥–Ω–∞–∑–Ω–∞—á–µ–Ω –¥–ª—è —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—á–∏–∫–æ–≤ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º, –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑—É—é—â–∏—Ö —è–∑—ã–∫–∏ C –∏ –°++ –¥–ª—è —Ç–æ–≥–æ, —á—Ç–æ–±—ã –æ–Ω–∏ –º–æ–≥–ª–∏ –±–æ–ª–µ–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–æ —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–≤–∞—Ç—å –ò–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω–µ—Ç-–ø—Ä–∏–ª–æ–∂–µ–Ω–∏—è. –ü–æ —Å—Ä–∞–≤–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—é —Å –° –∏ –°++, –°# –æ–±–ª–∞–¥–∞–µ—Ç –±–µ–∑–æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω—ã–º –∫–æ–¥–æ–º.

Programming languages (English)

Programming languages are formal languages ‚Äã‚Äãdesigned to describe programs and algorithms that allow a computer to perform a particular computational process, organize the management of various objects, etc. They represent a set of lexical, syntactic and semantic rules that determine the appearance programs and actions that the performer (computer) will perform under its control.

Programming languages ‚Äã‚Äãfall into two main categories: high-level languages ‚Äã‚Äãand low-level languages.

High level languages

High-level language (high-level language) - a programming language, the means of which provide a description of the problem in a visual, easily perceived form, convenient for the programmer. It does not depend on the internal machine codes of any type of computer, so programs written in high-level languages ‚Äã‚Äãrequire translation into machine codes by translator or interpreter programs. High-level languages ‚Äã‚Äãinclude Fortr, Python, JavaScript, C, C++, C#, Basic, Pascal, PHP, Ada, etc.

  • Fortran (–§–æ—Ä—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω) is the first high-level programming language that has received practical application, has a translator and has experienced further development. Developed between 1954 and 1957 by a group of programmers led by John Backus at IBM Corporation. The name Fortran is short for FORmula TRANslator (Formula Translator). Fortran is widely used primarily for scientific and engineering computing. One of the advantages of modern Fortran is a large number of programs and libraries of subroutines written on it (for example, for matrix algebra, differential equations, integral equations, mathematical statistics, etc.) The most common versions of this language are Fortran IV, Fortran 77 and Fortran 90. It is used on all classes of computers. Its latest version is also used on computers with a parallel architecture.
  • C (–°–∏) - A multi-purpose high-level programming language developed by Denis Ritchie in the early 1970s. based on the BCPL language. Used on minicomputer and PC. It is the base language of the Unix operating system, but it is also used outside this system to write fast and efficient software products, including operating systems. There are a number of popular versions of C for the IBM PC, including Turbo C (by Borland), Microsoft C and Quick C (by Microsoft), and Zortech C (by Symantec). Many of these versions also provide work with C and C++.
  • C++ (–°–∏++) - A high-level programming language created by Bjarne Stroustrap based on the C language. It is its extended version, which implements the principles of object-oriented programming. C++ is widely used for software development and is one of the most popular programming languages. The C++ syntax is inherited from the C language. Its scope includes the creation of operating systems, various application programs, device drivers, applications for embedded systems, high-performance servers, and computer games. There are many implementations of the C++ language, both free and commercial, and for various platforms. For example, on the x86 platform, these are GCC, Visual C++, Intel C++ Compiler, Embarcadero (Borland) C++ Builder, and others. C++ has had a huge impact on other programming languages, most notably Java and C#. For the IBM PC, the most popular system is Turbo C++ from Borland (USA).
  • C# (C Sharp) is a general-purpose object-oriented programming language developed in 1998-2001 by a group of Microsoft engineers led by Anders Hejlsberg and Scott Wilthaumot as an application development language for the Microsoft .NET Framework and .NET Core. It was subsequently standardized as ECMA-334 and ISO/IEC 23270. It is similar in nature to C++ and Java and is intended for C and C++ software developers to create Internet applications more efficiently. Compared to C and C++, C# has safe code.
  • Python (–ø–∏—Ç–æ–Ω, –ø–∞–π—Ç–æ–Ω) is a high-level general-purpose programming language with dynamic strong typing and automatic memory management, focused on improving developer productivity, code readability and quality, as well as ensuring the portability of programs written in it. The language is completely object-oriented in the sense that everything is an object. A feature of the language is the allocation of code blocks with whitespace indents. The syntax of the core language is minimalistic, due to which in practice there is rarely a need to refer to the documentation. The language itself is known as interpreted and is used, among other things, for writing scripts. Python is one of the most widely used languages, and a large number of projects have been implemented in it. Actively used by Google, most of the YouTube source code is written on it. It is also often used in the creation of robotic machines. The disadvantages of the language are the often slower operation and higher memory consumption of programs written in it compared to similar code written in compiled languages ‚Äã‚Äãsuch as C or C ++.
  • JavaScript is a general-purpose programming language that supports object-oriented, imperative, and functional styles. It is a cross-platform programming language and allows you to use one program on different operating systems - MacOS, Windows and Linux. Java is mainly used on the server side of backend projects and in the development of mobile applications for the Android operating system. Other projects written in Java include RuneScape, Yahoo, Amazon, eBay, LinkedIn, Assassin’s Creed, Minecraft, and God of War: Betrayal. Java is used to create the visual appearance of sites, often used in the development of cloud applications. The disadvantages of Java are the slow operation of programs and the high consumption of RAM.

Low level languages

Low-level language (low-level language) - a programming language designed for a certain type of computer and reflecting its internal machine code. This type includes assembly language, machine and machine-oriented languages.

  • Assembly language, assembler is a universal programming language, the structure of which is determined by command formats, machine language data and computer architecture. It is used by programmers in cases where it is impossible to use a high-level language or efficient programs in machine codes are required.
  • Machine language, (machine code, platform-oriented code) - the programming language of a particular computer, which is interpreted directly by the processor or firmware of this computer.
  • A machine-oriented language is a programming language that takes into account the structure and characteristics of a computer of a certain type or a specific computer.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Wowchemy

Wowchemy | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}

- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
  {{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation
